title: Nigeria: Unemployment Rate Rose to 8.2 Percent in Second Quarter - NBS
text:
Nigeria: Fighting Polio and the Burden of Tackling Fear 
The report showed that the number of underemployed in the labour force during the review quarter increased by 1,362,274 or 11.16 per cent, resulting in an increase in the underemployment rate to 18.3 per cent. 
The underemployed population rose to 13.5 million in Q2 from 12.2 million recorded in the first quarter of the year. 
The total numbers of people in full employment also dropped by 1,317,700 in the second quarter. 
The NBS stated that full employment meant people who did something for at least 40 hours and a drop in full employment meant those working less than 40 hours despite a rise in the labour force. 
The NBS attributed the drop in full employment to "job losses or previously fully employed persons choosing or being forced to work part time or in underemployment." 
The report revealed that the economically active population or working age population, which are persons within ages 15 to 64, increased from 102.8 million in the first quarter to 103.5 million in the second quarter of this year. 
"With an economically active or working age population of 103.5 million and labour force population of 74.0 million, this means 29.5 million persons within the economically active or working age population decided not to work for various reasons in Q2 2015 compared to 29.3 million in Q1 2015," the report stated.
